text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

From big cities to rural
towns, these leaders

are spearheading initiatives
that transcend profit margins,

prioritizing the well-being
and prosperity of all citizens
in their communities.
This is the voice of change.
Let's listen.

So my name is Fulvio Pagani.
I'm from Argentina.

I'm a director in Grupo
Arcor, Grupo Arcor

is a consumer
products company that

was born seven years ago
in Cordoba, Argentina,

a small town, where
everything started.

Nowadays, we have factories
all over South America
and recently in Africa.

So we export to more
than 120 countries.

And we are growing exponentially
in the last few years.
I'm based in Argentina.
I'm based in Cordoba, still.

So after going to my MBA in
the United States, in Boston,

I decided to return
to Argentina,

as I thought there was a
lot of opportunities for me

to come back, get
involved in the business.

And apart from that, there's
a lot of opportunities
in the environment.
So I'm very happy I got back.

Tell us about the
role that your company

plays in helping address
economic inequality.
Great.

So I think that
companies, in general,

have a very strong commitment
to addressing this issue.

I think it's very important that
it's not a decision that you
make in specific investments.

But it's a decision you
make every single day

when you make investments and
when you make new businesses.

So in particular, in
our company, what we do

is we try to develop
areas in Argentina that

are not the common areas
that many people would know.

So we go deep into the
country, and we go and develop
in small cities, towns.

And we try to go and develop the
opportunities for more people
there.

So with these new businesses,
what we normally try to get

is more universities
and high schools.
We work with them.

And we try to get
people and hire people
from these universities.

So, for example, in
the last few years,

we opened factories
in small towns

which converted later
to small cities,

where new universities
open facilities there,

so we can get professionals
adapted to what our needs are.
And we have been increasing.

This is not only
good for society,

because, clearly, we can see
there's a huge advantage,

but it's also good
for the business.

Because we get people who
grow with the business

and the loyalty is
just unparalleled.

So what we get is people who are
committed to the company, people

who just have seen
how the company has

grown, in the last few years,
thanks to these investments.

This is something that
my grandfather started.
And it was never a question.
This is how we do business.

And there's no
question that this

is how we should do things
moving forward in the future.

What would you say
is the number one

most important action that your
company is taking, specifically.

I think it's very important
to understand how businesses
and society get correlated.

I truly believe that businesses
are correlated with society
in everything they do.

So for me, it is
we get our talent

and we get the best people
working with these small towns,

working with people who may not
come from the same backgrounds
that like the directors, maybe.

But what we do need is
diversity, diversity

of backgrounds,
diversity of gender,

diversity of ethnics
and everything.

So I truly believe that
working with people,

who are different
from us or from me,

is what actually
creates the most value.

So for me it is--
what we've done

is working with universities,
trying to empower,

trying to get more
opportunities.

And the responsibility of the
business is to continue growing

and to keep on giving
opportunities, keep on growing.

As the business grows, there's
more opportunities out there
in the market.

And of course, I
think that's going

to create prosperity for any
country we are involved in.

But does this help
or hurt performance?
Is it neutral?

I think it's
absolutely positive.

I think what we have
seen is retention rates.

We've seen major improvements in
how committed people are working

with a company when you
give them the opportunity

to keep on
developing, to achieve

things they never
imagined they were
going to be able to do before.

So I think it's a
twofold win when

you get people loving what they
are doing, loving the company.

I think it's just a
no-brainer that you

need to invest in
those things you

want to actually look
for in the future

and get the company moving
in the right direction.

Would you have any
metrics that you

might be able to share with us,
whether it's retention rates?
Yeah, of course.

So retention rates
is a very good one.

But retention rates, like the
number of factories we open

in small towns and small cities
in Argentina or in small parts

of Brazil, for example== in
Chile, we've done the same.

We've recently opened
a factory in Angola.

So Angola, we're
creating jobs in Angola.

And that's actually
giving social mobility

and that's attacking economic
inequality, as we've said.

But I think the most
important thing is not
something about metrics.

It's something about
talking to the people

and actually getting to know the
stories behind those metrics.

When I talk to some people
that are part of the everyday,

of the company I am,
that's what fuels me

and what actually gives me
the fuel every single day is
knowing the stories.

And actually, there's the
responsibility of business,

of creating those
opportunities moving forward.

It's something
that no company can

keep on growing and
doing, in the future,
without having that social role.

And it sounds like
it was ingrained

when your grandfather started
the company many years ago.
So it's part of the culture.
Exactly.

Do you think that your peers,
whether you've met them

in business school or your
friends from around the world,

do you think they have
those same values?
So I think that we share values.

But I think it's very
hard for everybody
to see the same issues.

In order to see these
issues, you sometimes

need to actually go and visit
and put feet on the ground

and actually walk on the
streets and see that.

It's not easy for
business leaders
to actually see these issues.

When you see and when you
hear the conversations

and you hear some of the topics
that are being brought up,

and you see the reality of
many of parts of society,

we can see that there is
a big gap between what

the discussion is
been, right now,

and where some real
life issues are.

So I truly encourage
people to get out

there to go and visit,
go and have the talk.

I truly believe that, in order
to solve this, what we need

is to get our hands
in the issue and get
ourselves involved with it.

In order to do this,
there's only one way out.

And it's actually
to get involved.

Well, I think we're talking
about the next section

of questions here,
and that's advice.
Yeah.

So I wanted you to share
your advice specifically

about that, because
tackling inequality is
so hard for a business.

So based on your
experience so far,

and, clearly, you have so much
dedication to this issue, what

would you say if you wanted
to share one piece of advice

with other business leaders
who want to take action
but aren't sure how?

So of course, I have
a lot to learn yet.
And I have a lot--

I hope, in my
professional career,
I'm going to learn a lot.

But the only thing I would say,
the advice I gave my friends

and the advice I gave my
classmates while I was at HBS

was go out there, go out
there, see the reality,

see what things
people are living,

try to understand what
life is every day for them.

And once you see that,
what you're going to say
is I need to make a change.
I need to be a part of this.

So my only advice to them
would be just go out there,

visit, go out there,
learn, try to explore.

And once you get out
there, you're going to--

it's impossible not
to get involved,

because I think
it's in our genes
to try to solve those issues.

If we live in a better society,
everybody's going to be happier.

So I absolutely encourage
people to go out there, visit

and try to work and
solve things together.

Because if we are
trying to solve this

as individual parts, the
sum of the parts, I'm sure

it's going to create more
value than if we act all alone.

From your experience, is there
a willingness, from the workers,
to share and give you feedback?
Absolutely.
Absolutely.

At least it's the culture
I was brought up in.

So I was brought up in a
culture that being a manager

or being a director is
not sitting in an office

and making decisions
on building.

It's actually walking and
seeing how your products are

doing on the street,
actually understanding

how your consumer is
perceiving your products,

actually understanding what
your worker in a factory
is going through.

And that's the way
you make decisions.

If you make decisions sitting on
a desk, on a 30 story building,

I think you're not
connected to the reality
that many people are living.

And sometimes,
you're not connected

to the reality of the consumer
that is buying your product.

So what you need to go-- is
go out there, actually go

and get to know people, go
and get to know reality.

And once you actually see that,
decisions are much easier.

How do you view the
role of business schools

in helping address
economic inequality?
You've had a certain experience.

Your friends have had
other experiences.

Do you think that
business schools
should change curriculum?
What do you think?

The role that business
schools have is key on this.
My experience at HBS was--

I remember saying, "educating
the leaders of the future that
are going to change the world."

And I actually believe that
in order to change anything,

the first step is to
go and get to know it.

And what I truly believe
is that business schools
need to show what reality is.

When I talk about
this, it is find people

from different backgrounds,
different areas,

different nationalities
and everything.

But it's very hard for all of
them to expose their experience,

to expose what they've done
if business school does not
create the space for that.

So I truly believe
that curriculum

and extracurricular activities
are key for this in order

to expose, to the whole class
of any business schools,

to these issues that
society is facing.

These leaders are going to
have an impact in the future.

But in order to
have an impact, we

need to know where
we're starting from.

And I'm sure that we're
going to have a very, very

good, good impact if we're
able to understand reality,
right now.

Because it's the smartest
people who are going
to be working on these issues.

And they're going to be able
to put forward solutions.
Thank you so much.

Can you talk to us about whether
you are continuing or launching

any initiatives that
address economic inequality?

What challenges do you see
ahead for 2024 and beyond

and maybe what keeps you up at
night on this type of an issue?

So while there is an issue, I
think that all businesspeople
need to address it.
And we need to work on this.

But it's an issue that is going
to take many years to solve.

And if we all work
together, and if we all

are willing to work
towards a solution,

I think it's going to
progressively get better.

We work on the right
path, we're going

to see the benefits in
the very short term.

So there's nothing
that is keeping me up

at night except
from knowing that we

need to take steps, every single
day, in the right direction.

We just need to do
things every single day.

And every single
decision we do, we

need to be aware of
society and the impact
it may have in society.

So, I mean, that is a challenge,
because it requires patience
and persistence, perseverance.

So how do you help spread
the word about this?

So the first thing is
I'm still learning.

And this is how I
would say it is.
It's a learning.

Every day, you learn about how
to be that person that actually
talks about these issues.

And you actually
have a position.

And at least you open
yourself about what you think
and what your position is.

And once you're doing
that, what you're actually

putting on the table
is some discussions.

And at least you're moving
forward the conversation.

So that's what I'm
doing right now.

I know that I'm like--
hopefully, when one day, I

will retire, I will
say, every single day, I

learn about how to find
more and better solutions.

And that's the learning
curve that we all want

in our professional
lives, to keep

on learning every single
day about how we can keep
on pushing the conversation.

But at least, what
I'm doing right now

is I'm standing in a
place that I can say like,
hey, I'm here to learn.
I'm here to solve these issues.
I'm here to at least discuss.

Let's move the
conversation forward.

And let's start
sharing our thoughts

about what is wrong,
what is right,

and what we can do
to keep on moving.
Thank you.

And so as you're
thinking about sharing

your thoughts and
your experiences

and your observations, do
people in your generation--

are you sharing these
thoughts on social media?

How might you be doing it
aside from conferences?

So I think social media
is a very powerful tool.

It's a very powerful
tool for both sides,

for a good conversation
and for hate, too.

So we have to be very
careful about social media.

Not everything that
you put up there

is going to be treated
in the same way.

So when we talk
about social media,

I truly encourage very
responsible use of social media.

I encourage people to actually
get with social media,

with a good message and not to
communicate hate through it.

But it's very hard to, nowadays,
communicate in a safe way.
I think it's only a tool.

The message behind it
is important thing.

So I truly believe that
tools are just it-- tools.

And what we need to do
is the best use of it.

So is there anything else
that you would like to share?

So I believe that economic
inequality is an issue that we
all should be talking about.

It's something that
should be brought up.

And the discussion
should be on the table.

Once we do that, what
we are going to have is

we're going to have more
people talking about it, trying
to find solutions about it.

And what we're going
to see is we're

going to get to the
people who can actually

make decisions and
make an influence.

And what we're
going to try to do

is try to mark the right
path moving forward.

And I think it's a
continuous learning curve.

But if we are able to
have that discussion,

I think it's going to go and
benefit all of us as a society

and as people who
are in this society.
Thank you so much, Fulvio.
Thank you.
It was a pleasure.
Brilliant.
It was a pleasure.
